creditline: Gift of Roxy Ballard in loving memory of Richard Campbell
description: small image of Mars at enter holding a club aloft to strike a kneeling figure at his feet, inside an octagonal cartouche, surrounded by swords, arrows, wreaths and garlands, pair young caryatid-like figures wearing large helmets and carrying shields and arrows, pair of winged lions with men's heads, pairs of armored gloves and ribbons
inscription:
Title and Inscription

LRC, printed in black: [6]; LLC in the print, in black: [(monogram) Sno (?) & fecit]; on back, in pencil: [11(illegible)]; on back, in brown ink: [(illegible)]
provenance: Richard Campbell, Minneapolis (until 1993; given to Ballard); Roxy Ballard, Minneapolis (1993-2014; given to MIA)
signed: bottom center, printed in black: [MARS OU LA GUERE]
text: Jean Demosthene Dugourc was a leading designer during the reign of Louis XVI. In 1764, he traveled to Rome as part of the retinue of the Comte de Cany. There he drew directly from the antique. After his return to France, his work for prominent patrons helped to spread the taste for arabesques and the Etruscan style: figures of Graces, winged women playing the lyre, snakes, sphinxes, scrolls, cornucopias, figure drawings in shades, medallions—the type of work plainly in evidence in the present allegorical print which represents the god Mars and the act of war.
title: Mars ou La Guerre (Mars or War), plate 6 from "Arabesques, Inventes et graves"
